bioghist.p: In 1742, Henry [Heinrich] Melchior Muhlenberg (1711-1787) arrived in Philadelphia to assume pastoral duties at the largest German Lutheran parish in colonial America. Under the sponsorship of the Francke Foundations—an educational, missionary, and commercial institution in the Prussian city of Halle—he became the prime organizer of churched Lutheranism in America. Muhlenberg was also an influential cultural leader with contact to colonial dignitaries such as Benjamin Franklin, other religious leaders such as George Whitfield, and the Hanoverian court in London. Married in 1745 to Anna Maria Weiser, a daughter of Pennsylvania’s principal go-between with the Lenape, Muhlenberg was not only a formidable figure in his own right, but was the progenitor of what became in effect a German-American dynasty of high-level public officials. His three sons, all trained to be pastors, won fame in politics science, and academia. Peter rose to major general of the Continental Army (receiving the commendation of George Washington), was elected Vice President of Pennsylvania and for four terms, served in Congress; Friedrich, also a member of Congress, was elected first Speaker of the House; Gotthilf excelled in botany and, as president of Franklin College, vigorously promoted American higher education.

scopecontent.p: The MOP collection contains approximately 551 linear feet, with material dating from 1748 to 1962. The archives holds 28 volumes of Henry Melchior Muhlenberg’s personal journals, correspondence, financial accounts and family papers. Also in the collection are Friedrich’s diary (25 October 1770 to 8 August 1774) and miscellaneous personal papers, as well as Gotthilf’s sermon outlines, miscellaneous personal correspondence, and an 1815 copper plate portrait. In addition to Henry Muhlenberg’s personal papers, the collection holds the personal papers of several nationally know theologians: the Revs. J. H. C. Helmuth (1745-1825), William J. Mann (1819-1892), Charles Porterfield Krauth (1823-1883), Henry Eyster Jacobs (1844-1932), and Charles Michael Jacobs (1875-1938). Organizational archives in this collection include the following Philadelphia churches and Lutheran entities: St. Michael’s & Zion German Lutheran Church (1730-present); St. Michael’s Lutheran Church, Germantown (1728-present); Old St. John’s English Lutheran Church (1806-2002); Lutheran Home at Germantown Foundation (1859-present); The Evangelical Lutheran Ministerium of Pennsylvania & Adjacent States (1748-1962); The General Council of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in North America (1866-1918); New York and New England Conferences, Augustana Evangelical Lutheran Church (1860-1962).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
